5/5 These laws were passed with the promise they would improve the forests. After more than four decades, I think we are entitled to ask, how are the forests doing?

Read Congressman McClintock's full House Floor remarks here: https://t.co/9CcvDoOhJT

1308859882465091584.text: 4/5 Really? These environmental laws generally apply only to public lands. Today, you can easily tell the boundaries between private & public lands solely by the condition of the forests. How clever of the climate only to decimate the public lands.

1308859881450016768.text: 3/5 We have been trying for years to reform these laws, resume active forest management & restore our forests to health. Yet the environmental leftists have blocked us every year. Instead, politicians use the excuse of climate change.

1308859880476999682.text: 2/5 Draconian restrictions on logging, grazing, prescribed burns & herbicide use on public lands have made modern land management endlessly time consuming & ultimately cost prohibitive. A single tree thinning plan typically takes four years & more than 800 pages of analysis.

1308859879474462720.text: 1/5 Last week President Trump came to CA to be briefed on the horrific fires raging in CA. Instead he got a lecture from Gov. Newsom & his staff on climate change. Beginning in the 1970s we imposed environmental laws that have made the management of our lands all but impossible.

1306406227388166144.text: 3/4 We've had an 80% decline in timber harvested out of our federal forests since 1980 and we've had a concomitant increase in acreage destroyed by fire.

1306406226717110272.text: 2/4 Then, in the 1970s we began imposing environmental laws that have made it all but impossible to carry out that timber. What we've seen over those decades, is increasingly severe forest fires.

1306406225970475008.text: 1/4 Excess timber comes out of the forest in one of two ways, it's either carried out or it burns out. We used to carry it out, it was called logging. We had healthy forests and we had a thriving economy.
